dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back to the show! We've got a lot to unpack this week, particularly across the pond, where Boris Johnson has been, uh, celebrating a successful vote.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back to the show! We've got a lot to unpack this week, particularly across the pond, where Boris Johnson has been, uh, celebrating a successful vote.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has warned that rebel Conservative MPs risk undermining Brexit negotiations as he urged them to vote against opposition parties' plan to delay, or block a no deal exit from the European Union.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he really has, hasn't he? I mean, he was out there thanking Conservative MPs for their "steadfast support," you know, for ensuring those Brexit negotiations could continue despite, like, all the opposition trying to delay a no-deal exit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he really has, hasn't he? I mean, he was out there thanking Conservative M P s for their steadfast support, you know, for ensuring those Brexit negotiations could continue despite, like, all the opposition trying to delay a no-deal exit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has warned that rebel Conservative MPs risk undermining Brexit negotiations as he urged them to vote against opposition parties' plan...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and he really praised their "wisdom" for voting against Jeremy Corbyn. And, uh, he completely doubled down on that October 31st deadline, come what may.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and he really praised their wisdom for voting against Jeremy Corbyn. And, uh, he completely doubled down on that October thirty first deadline, come what may.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson urged MPs to vote against Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and his pointless delay as he doubled down on his oft-repeated promise to leave the trading bloc by October 31 come what may.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that Oct 31st promise, still very much there. And heâ€™s arguing now that the chances of a deal are plummeting because, apparently, the EU can see that Britain doesn't actually *want* a deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that Oct thirty first promise, still very much there. And he's arguing now that the chances of a deal are plummeting because, apparently, the E U can see that Britain doesn't actually want a deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He added that the chances of a deal are rising because the EU can see that Britain wants a deal...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a fascinating spin, isn't it? But then, the election rumours. He urged MPs to delay their actions, fearing a dissolution of Parliament, but then, he's quoted saying, "I do want an election, you do want an election." Like, which is it, Boris?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a fascinating spin, isn't it? But then, the election rumours. He urged M P s to delay their actions, fearing a dissolution of Parliament, but then, he's quoted saying, I do want an election, you do want an election. Like, which is it, Boris?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson speaking outside 10 Downing Street said: I don't want an election, you don't want an election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, it's a bit of a mixed message, isn't it? Seems he's encouraging opposition Tory MPs to stand for election in the *next* election if they *don't* support his attempts to block a no-deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, it's a bit of a mixed message, isn't it? Seems he's encouraging opposition Tory M P s to stand for election in the next election if they don't support his attempts to block a no-deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It follows reports that Johnson is gearing up to expel or block opposition Tory MPs from standing for election in the next election, if they support the opposition attempts to pass a law to block the U.K. from leaving the EU without a trade deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, essentially, he's saying, "My way or the highway" to his own party members.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, essentially, he's saying, My way or the highway to his own party members.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And the opposition, they're not sitting still either. They're reportedly proposing a three-month Brexit acceleration if Johnson doesn't strike a deal at the EU Council on October 19th.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And the opposition, they're not sitting still either. They're reportedly proposing a three-month Brexit acceleration if Johnson doesn't strike a deal at the E U Council on October nineteenth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Opposition MPs are reportedly proposing a three-month Brexit delay if Johnson does not strike a deal at the European Council, a summit of EU leaders, on October 19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's a pretty aggressive timeline. And all this, uh, is unfolding after his controversial move to prorogue Parliament, right? Like, suspend it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a pretty aggressive timeline. And all this, uh, is unfolding after his controversial move to prorogue Parliament, right? Like, suspend it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnsons move to suspendor prorogueParliament last week under the guise of a procedure known as the Queens speech... means that oppositions MPs have just a week to draft a bill and secure the votes needed to make it law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. That whole Queen's Speech thing, which, you know, it gave the opposition a whole year to draft a bill and secure the votes needed. So it's still, like, very much in play.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, totally. That whole Queen's Speech thing, which, you know, it gave the opposition a whole year to draft a bill and secure the votes needed. So it's still, like, very much in play.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...means that oppositions MPs have just a week to draft a bill and secure the votes needed to make it law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which means, as it stands, the UK isn't even due to leave on October 31st, with or without a deal. That's a key takeaway from all this.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which means, as it stands, the U K isn't even due to leave on October thirty first, with or without a deal. That's a key takeaway from all this.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As it stands, the U.K. is due to leave the European Union on October 31 with or without a deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Which is wild, right? Considering everything he's been saying.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, right? Considering everything he's been saying.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, uh, speaking of wild, did you see the reports about the protests outside Downing Street? Chanting "support the coup."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, uh, speaking of wild, did you see the reports about the protests outside Downing Street? Chanting support the coup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Protesters could be heard chanting stop the coup outside Downing Street as Johnson delivered his speech.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, thousands out there, rallying against the prorogation. I mean, his opponents are calling it "unconstitutional" and "undemocratic."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, thousands out there, rallying against the prorogation. I mean, his opponents are calling it unconstitutional and undemocratic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thousands turned out across cities in the U.K. over the weekend to rally against the suspension of Parliament which was branded unconstitutional and undemocratic by Johnson's opponents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's just a lot, isn't it? And if an election *does* happen this year, it would be the third in five years. That's a pretty surprising fact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just a lot, isn't it? And if an election does happen this year, it would be the third in five years. That's a pretty surprising fact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If an election is called this year, it would be the third in five years in the U.K., following votes in 2015 and 2017.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Can you even imagine? It's been quite the, uh, political rollercoaster over there.

dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. What a week in UK politics.
